Today is Juneteenth, also called Freedom Day and Emancipation Day, celebrates the abolition of slavery in the United States. On June 19, 1865, Union soldiers arrived in Texas to deliver news that President Lincoln has issued the Emancipation Proclamation, freeing the enslaved. Although Lincoln's Proclamation was issued on January 1, 1863, it took nearly two and half years for word to travel from Washington to Texas. By then, Texas had amassed more than 250,000 slaves.

Since 1865, Juneteenth has been informally celebrated throughout the country however in 1980, Texas became the first state to recognize it as an official holiday. Shortly thereafter, other states also proclaimed the holiday. Today, Juneteenth is a celebration of African-American freedom, heritage and culture observed through songs, communal cookouts and parades.

Today is International Picnic Day!!
International Picnic Day celebrates gathering together outdoors to eat and enjoy one another's company, which has traditionally been called a Picnic. The true origin of International Picnic Day is unknown, but can be traced back to the end of the French Revolution and the Victorian Era. Picnics were ways for people to escape the restrictions of etiquette and formality. Have a picnic in your backyard or find a nice spot at a park, enjoy the beautiful day and have fun!!

Hi Pumas! Today we are going to make Cinna-Twists. This recipe is very simple and tasty. You'll need some refrigerator biscuits, butter, cinnamon and sugar!

Ingredients: 1 can refrigerated biscuits, 4 tablespoons butter, 1/2 cup sugar, 2 teaspoons cinnamon. Directions: Preheat oven to 425 degrees. Cover cookie sheet with aluminum foil and grease it. Cut up butter, place in a small bowl and melt in the microwave for 1 minute. Mix sugar and cinnamon in a small bowl. Carefully pop open the biscuits, Flatten each biscuit into an oval. Using the wet dry hand method, dip each oval into the melted butter with your left hand, then using your right hand, place the biscuit in the cinnamon sugar mix using a small spoon. Twist the oval to make a twisted, stick like shape. Bake for 5-6 minutes. Let cool and serve, May be drizzled with glaze or served with frosting. Enjoy!

NHA Students Show Compassion!

After earning $100 for jumping in a pool of icy water, Amaya decided to use half of her money to buy school supplies for children who may not have them at home. She and her sister, Arya, both attendees of Plymouth Scholars, made academic “goodie bags”. These bags were filled with pencils, erasers, paper, and more. These bags are at Canton Charter Academy, under the awning, on the wooden bench. The girls want each family to know, “If you need materials, come and get them.”

We are thankful to have students like Amaya and Arya who are showing compassion for others during this difficult time.

If your family is in need of supplies, please drop by Canton Charter Academy and take what you need.

Way to go Amaya and Arya!

I'm sure you have noticed over the past month the "Beautification" of our school entrance - how could you miss it? Your families generous donations to the PTO, helped fund the PTO Beautification Committee Back to School September Display. Also, with these generous donations the PTO Beautification Committee was able to purchase 3 large planter boxes that will be used for years to come. Thank you to Ms. Haley for all her hard work on this project and her magical green thumb!

Last week the PTO Beautification Committee put together our Fall Display and would like to thank two local businesses for generously donating to it. “Colony Irrigation” donated all the mums, hail bails and corn stalks and “Three Cedar Farms” donated all the pumpkins and gourds that will be out in front of our school on display.

If you know a local business that might like to donate to one our upcoming displays or if you have a green thumb and would like to help please contact the chairperson Crystal Haley @ chaley48167@msn.com.
